author: Odeinoichus
title: It's a Bird. It's a Plane. It's a Spaceship???
review:
Set #71236 Superman Fun Pack: Another member of the Justice League joins the team and it’s Superman, the iconic and God like being with powers beyond belief. In LEGO form he’s a decent addition to any team, unfortunately this Fun Pack doesn’t include much aside from the character himself.

Packaging

Standing prominently in his typical heroic pose Superman’s Metropolis is visible in the background, a stunning bit of artwork of the character in 3D while the toy is shown off prominently on the front and back. Nothing much else to say here.

Parts

This set has a lot more red and blue pieces than I see typically used by LEGO in these types of elements. Wings, cheese slopes and the like are typically in different colours, so seeing them here is great.

Minifigures

Superman: This version doesn’t offer up any new elements, Superman is using the same torso, dual-sided head, hair piece and cape we’ve seen across the DC Super Hero line, so honestly there isn’t much being offered here compared to some of the other sets.

The build

Hover Pod: Giving Superman a vehicle is a bit of an odd decision, but the build for the initial model is fairly decent and uses a lot of fun elements to good effect. This is meant to be the ship Superman arrived on Earth on, and I can see that from the design.

Krypton Striker: This build for the secondary model is a bit unusual in its design and part placement; however it features some nice ideas though it could have been executed slightly better. Still I was satisfied with the build and it’s still a fun toy to play with on or off the tag.

Super Stealth Pod: This third build makes what looks like a Kryptonite Cryo Chamber. It is designed to look slightly like the pod that Lois is placed into in Man of Steel, considering this the model is a fairly nice little build, if a bit lacking due to the need to use only one set of parts whereas the digital build seems a bit more coherent in its overall design.

The completed model

Hover Pod & Alternate Models: All three of these models, once built, are highly fun little vehicles to play around with. They don’t 100% match their digital counterparts in some areas, but overall they are all three fairly impressive and decent enough for something to build. The only issue I have is why Superman needed a vehicle when he can already fly, even in space… granted earlier comics did not include this power from what I recall. That being said, it would have been relatively hard to find something suitable to make for him.

Ultimately though it could have been worse. At least they do a good job with making a ship based around the life pod Jor-El used to send his son to Earth in the first place. I’m not sure if it matches in-comic appearances of that craft, but it does look like LEGO Superman would have been inside this particular vehicle when he was sent to Earth.

The Digital Content

Adventure World: It’s another character granting access to the DC Adventure World, and I can’t believe how superfluous this seems since Batman comes with the Starter Set so you should already have access to it, so why bother buying any of the ancillary sets from DC? Mostly for the Characters I’d say.

Character & Vehicle Abilities: Naturally, Superman is quite powerful. He has the iconic Flying ability with his own Theme song playing as he flies, until the tune cuts out for some reason after a while. He is Invulnerable, which means he can’t die, has Laser and Freezing Breath can destroy Cracked LEGO Objects and can Dive under water. He also has the X-Ray Vision ability.

The Hover Pod can interact with Flight Docks and Cargo Hooks, the secondary form of the Krypton Striker can do all of that and also has a Special Weapon while the Super Stealth Pod drops this ability in favor of Destroying Silver LEGO Objects.

Overall opinion

This set is utterly pointless in most respects, and I’m not saying that from a perspective of it being bad. No I mean this set is pointless because DC Adventure World is already unlocked with the Starter Pack and the other characters serve no real purpose in the game, some of them have certain puzzle solving abilities and their vehicles can be fun and interesting to see in action or play with in physical form.

So I’d recommend this set mostly for fans of Superman who wants him in their LEGO Dimensions game as a character. If you are only interested in unlocking everything Superman can easily be skipped. So to summarize Recommended to fans, otherwise skip it safely with no fear of missing something exclusive.
